instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.R7402: What is R7402? Resistor between PPVIN_S0_CPUIMVP and CPUIMVP_TON. TON stands for TIME ON â€“ CPUIMVP_TON configures the buck converter for the CPU based on its input power supply. If this resistor is blown, the machine will turn on but not have any image, chime, or POST, because CPU vcore will be missing. This resistor is often the first to corrode because it is along a high voltage rail and it is right on the edge of the board, check this on 2011-2012 model Macbook Pros that turn on and do not chime. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short on <SIGNAL>PPDDR_S3_REG</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Getting really frustrated by this board and I need someone smarter than me to explain what is going on.
When I got the board it was water damaged but started with RAM beeping.

I found that there was no <SIGNAL>PPDDR_S3_REG</SIGNAL> voltage, and there was a short on the rail.

I have now replaced every capacitor around <TRANSISTOR>Q7330</TRANSISTOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7335</TRANSISTOR>.

When I take of <TRANSISTOR>Q7335</TRANSISTOR> the short to ground is gone. I have replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7335</TRANSISTOR> four times now :(

The short is worse when the board is warm, 0,010V in diode mode and slowly gets to around 0,100V when somewhat cooled.
When I take <TRANSISTOR>Q7335</TRANSISTOR> off the board it immediately measures 0,370V

The donor boards measures 0,370V before I take the <TRANSISTOR>Q7335</TRANSISTOR> off.

If anyone have any idea what's going on here please tell me.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short on <SIGNAL>PPDDR_S3_REG</SIGNAL>
threads.message: You are measuring on a scrap board without CPU I bet. Working board has 0,150 on diode mode when cold. Pin 16 and 17 on <CHIP>U7300</CHIP> high? I bet just a dead <CHIP>U7300</CHIP> if the enables are present.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short on <SIGNAL>PPDDR_S3_REG</SIGNAL>
threads.message: The boards all have CPUs, so 0,150 is okey? I have replaced <CHIP>U7300</CHIP> as well. But now the board won't start anymore

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short on <SIGNAL>PPDDR_S3_REG</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Now that the board is cold I get 0.118

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short on <SIGNAL>PPDDR_S3_REG</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I ask again, are the enables present on <CHIP>U7300</CHIP>?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short on <SIGNAL>PPDDR_S3_REG</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I'm sorry, but should they present even if it doesn't start anymore?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short on <SIGNAL>PPDDR_S3_REG</SIGNAL>
threads.message: To answer you question, I do get 3.12 on pin 16, an 0V on pin 17. I now need to figure out why it won't start anymore

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short on <SIGNAL>PPDDR_S3_REG</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Totally dead now? Of course there must be some life for enables to be present.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short on <SIGNAL>PPDDR_S3_REG</SIGNAL>
threads.message: No not totally, I have 1V on L7100

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short on <SIGNAL>PPDDR_S3_REG</SIGNAL>
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short on <SIGNAL>PPDDR_S3_REG</SIGNAL>
threads.message: No but PPBUS is only 12.26V, I'll look into it tomorrow.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short on <SIGNAL>PPDDR_S3_REG</SIGNAL>
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short on <SIGNAL>PPDDR_S3_REG</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Yes, I know. I'm stuck on this one. If I try to start it in SMC bypass its starts but with no CPU PPVCore. I do however get 1.5V on <SIGNAL>PPDDR_S3_REG</SIGNAL> when it starts.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short on <SIGNAL>PPDDR_S3_REG</SIGNAL>
threads.message: It had 3 beeps when you started so CPU Vcore must have been present. PPBUS at 12.26 indicates at least an SMC problem too, unless in SMC bypass of course

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short on <SIGNAL>PPDDR_S3_REG</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Yes I know :) I don't understand why I don't have CPU Vcore anymore, I am considering swapping the SMC, but I thought I should address the CPU Vcore issue first.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short on <SIGNAL>PPDDR_S3_REG</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Could be anything. <RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR> is common, besides that it can be anything that prevents the CPU from setting the voltage by talking to <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>. PPBUS still at 12.26 and green light is ok?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short on <SIGNAL>PPDDR_S3_REG</SIGNAL>
threads.message: This is going to the donor pile, I replaced the SMC and got 12.56V on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> for about a minute and one of the battery SDA lines were 8.4V before it disappeared and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> went down again to 12.26V :(. There must be some serious issues with this board.
